captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger BolderBaking
French Macaron "Donuts"

French Macarons are delicate and delicious
and extremely finicky to make. Michelle D

trusts me to show you how to make them. The
thing is: I've never made them before. I spent

the week making batch after batch until I
got them right. So today, I'm not just going

to show you how to make regular macarons.
I'm going to show you how to make BIG & BOLD
Jelly Donut Macarons. So let's get baking!

Ada Law asked me to show you the best French
Macaron recipe. Now the ingredients are always

the same, it's the technique that people really
struggle with. So I'm hoping today to make
it easy for you and for me.

We're going to start out with a clean metal
or glass bowl. Not plastic because plastic

soaks up grease. And make sure also that your
beaters are clean because you don't want any
grease in your egg whites.

We're going to whip our egg whites in the
bowl until they form soft peaks.

For your eggs whites, it's really important
that there's no yolk in them and that they're

room temperature. Room temperature makes them
really easy to whip.

When your egg whites have reached soft peaks,
we're going to slowly add in the caster sugar
spoonful by spoonful.

And we're going to whip our egg whites until
they're thick and shiny.

And this is what you want, a nice stiff meringue.
And this is going to give your macaron really
great body and lift.

Next we're going to sift our ground almonds
and our confectioners sugar into our egg whites.

And we do this to get out any lumps in the
sugar and in the almond meal. Any almond meal

left in the sieve can't go into the macarons
but always set it aside to use it in something
else.

Now we are at the most crucial part of the
macaron technique, and it's the folding in
of the almond flour into the eggwhites.

My tip to success is concentrate on your mixes.
Go slow and count. 2.

And just gently go around the bowl and fold
it all in.

I do the same movement around the bowl each
time. It just makes it easier to count.

As you can see it's really thick. It's nice
and bubbly. But we're still not there yet.
We've got more to go.

You can see it's starting to loosen up a little
bit.
Keep folding your mix over.
Our mix is starting to get a little bit looser.

So we're almost there but keep going. So stop
mixing
And take a look at your mix. And see how long

it takes to fall off your spatula. It takes
quite a long time.

It's like thick gooey lava. And when it lands
in the bowl it takes a while to disappear.
This is what we're looking for.
This took me around 37 mixes.

Ok. I'm pretty sure we got it perfect so let's
pipe these guys out and get them in the oven.

An easy way to fill your piping bag is to
sit it in a cup and fill it while it's standing
up.

Before we start piping, prepare your tray
with a nice big sheet of parchment paper and

just make sure it hasn't been used before
and there's no grease on it.

Also, use a good quality baking tray that
has a nice thick bottom to protect your macarons.

We're going to pipe our macarons onto this
stencil

and I'm going to put a link in the description
below so you can print it off yourselves.

Pipe your macaron by putting a little bit
of pressure on the bag and just filling up
the circle.

And remembering it will spread a little bit
too.

These rounds are going to be the base for
the macaron donuts.

For the tops of the donuts, put very little
pressure on your bag and just draw around
the outside of the circle.

The circle will get smaller in the middle
as they rest so try and do a thin line.

Before we let our macarons rest, you want
to take the tray and bang it against a hard

countertop to release any air bubbles that
might be in there.

So the hard part is over. Now we're going
to let them rest for an hour. We're going

to let them form a skin and by resting they
develop these lovely feet that give them that

lift. Also, while they're resting don't let
them sit anywhere humid. They do not like

humidity so take them into another room. Put
them somewhere dry and it will help them out a lot.

While the macarons are drying, we're going
to make our jelly buttercream filling.

In a previous video, I've made my signature buttercream
and I put a link for that in the description below.

To this, I'm going to add good quality raspberry
jelly.

You don't have to use raspberry jelly, I just
think it works really well.

You can use strawberry or whatever kind you
like.

If you haven't done so already, don't forget
to SUBSCRIBE to my channel for more great
recipes like this one.

Now that our filling is done, we're going
to pop it into the fridge until we need it.

The macarons have bee resting for an hour
and you know when they're ready when you touch

them and you can feel a bit of a skin and
it's not sticky against your finger so now

they're ready. We have the oven well pre-heated
at 300 degrees F and we're going to bake them
for 15 minutes.

Our macarons are out of the oven and we know
that we made a perfect mix because they look great.

They have all of their little feet on the
bottom

and they're nice and smooth on top. And they
didn't spread out too much.

These are going to make gorgeous little donut
macarons.

Let your macarons go totally cold and we're
going to transform them into jelly donuts.

To decorate our macarons, we're going to need
a variety of sprinkles and a frosting made
of confectioner's sugar and water.

Frost the top of your donuts and spread your
glaze evenly.
Decorate it with your favorite sprinkles.
Then turn over your flat base

and pipe the raspberry filling around the
edges.
and add a drop of jelly in the middle.
Then place on your glazed top.

You can create a variety of colorful and delicious
flavors.
So there is a favorite for everyone!

Thanks so much for watching and don't forget
to SUBSCRIBE to my channel by clicking the

box below. I'll see back here again next Thursday
for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: French Macaron "Donuts" (Easy to Make Recipe) - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 23

comments.text:
Hey Gemma here is some food for thought! Macarons and macaroons are 
actually 2 different cookies! You actually made macaRONS which are the 
French cookie and macaROONS are actually made out of coconut and kinda 
looks like toasted lumpy cookies! I would love it if you made some coconut 
macaroons to accompany these macarons! Here's also an article that kinda 
gives the run down on the two cookies :)

http://shopruche.com/blog/difference-between-macarons-and-macaroons/

I hope I hear from ya to hear your thoughts!﻿
